content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <feed xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom"> <title>Department of Chemistry</title> <link href="http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/721" rel="alternate"/> <subtitle>Cambridge Chemistry</subtitle> <id>http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/721</id> <updated>2015-03-12T02:54:01Z</updated> <dc:date>2015-03-12T02:54:01Z</dc:date> <entry> <title>Post-assembly Modification of Kinetically Metastable FeII 2L3 Triple Helicates</title> <link href="http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/246977" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name>Roberts, Derrick A.</name> </author> <author> <name>Castilla, Ana M.</name> </author> <author> <name>Ronson, Tanya K.</name> </author> <author> <name>Nitschke, Jonathan R.</name> </author> <id>http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/246977</id> <updated>2015-03-11T16:40:47Z</updated> <published>2014-05-23T00:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">Post-assembly Modification of Kinetically Metastable FeII 2L3 Triple Helicates Roberts, Derrick A.; Castilla, Ana M.; Ronson, Tanya K.; Nitschke, Jonathan R. We report the covalent post-assembly modification of kinetically metastable amine-bearing FeII2L3 triple helicates via acylation and azidation. Covalent modification of the metastable helicates prevented their reorganization to the thermodynamically favored FeII4L4 tetrahedral cages, thus trapping the system at the non-equilibrium helicate structure. This functionalization strategy also conveniently provides access to a higher-order tris(porphyrinatoruthenium)\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdhelicate complex that would be difficult to prepare by de novo ligand synthesis. This is the final published version. It first appeared at http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/ja5042397. </summary> <dc:date>2014-05-23T00:00:00Z</dc:date> </entry> <entry> <title>The Most Reactive Amide As a Transition-State Mimic For cis\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdtrans Interconversion</title> <link href="http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/246951" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name>Komarov, Igor V.</name> </author> <author> <name>Yanik, Stanislav</name> </author> <author> <name>Ishchenko, Aleksandr Yu.</name> </author> <author> <name>Davies, John E.</name> </author> <author> <name>Goodman, Jonathan M.</name> </author> <author> <name>Kirby, Anthony J.</name> </author> <id>http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/246951</id> <updated>2015-03-11T14:37:39Z</updated> <published>2014-12-22T00:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">The Most Reactive Amide As a Transition-State Mimic For cis\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdtrans Interconversion Komarov, Igor V.; Yanik, Stanislav; Ishchenko, Aleksandr Yu.; Davies, John E.; Goodman, Jonathan M.; Kirby, Anthony J. 1-Azatricyclo[3.3.1.13,7]decan-2-one (3), the parent compound of a rare class of 90\ufffd\ufffd-twisted amides, has finally been synthesized, using an unprecedented transformation. These compounds are of special interest as transition-state mimics for the enzyme-catalyzed cis\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdtrans rotamer interconversion of amides involved in peptide and protein folding and function. The stabilization of the amide group in its high energy, perpendicular conformation common to both systems is shown for the rigid tricyclic system to depend, as predicted by calculation, on its methyl group substitution pattern, making 3 by some way the most reactive known \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdamide\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd. This is the final published version of the article, originally published in the Journal of the American Chemical Society, 2015, 137 (2), pp 926\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd93, DOI: 10.1021/ja511460a </summary> <dc:date>2014-12-22T00:00:00Z</dc:date> </entry> <entry> <title>Base-Mediated Cascade Rearrangements of Aryl-Substituted Diallyl Ethers</title> <link href="http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/246942" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name>Reid, Jolene P.</name> </author> <author> <name>McAdam, Catherine A.</name> </author> <author> <name>Johnston, Adam J. S.</name> </author> <author> <name>Grayson, Matthew N.</name> </author> <author> <name>Goodman, Jonathan M.</name> </author> <author> <name>Cook, Matthew J.</name> </author> <id>http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/246942</id> <updated>2015-03-09T15:43:03Z</updated> <published>2014-12-16T00:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">Base-Mediated Cascade Rearrangements of Aryl-Substituted Diallyl Ethers Reid, Jolene P.; McAdam, Catherine A.; Johnston, Adam J. S.; Grayson, Matthew N.; Goodman, Jonathan M.; Cook, Matthew J. Two base mediated cascade rearrangement reactions of diallyl ethers were developed leading to selective [2,3]-Wittig-oxy-Cope and isomerization-Claisen rearrangements. Both diaryl and aryl-silyl substituted 1,3-substituted propenyl substrates were examined and each exhibits unique reactivity and different reaction pathways. Detailed mechanistic and computational analysis was conducted which demonstrated that the role of the base and solvent were key to the reactivity and selectivity observed. Crossover experiments also suggest that these reactions proceed with a certain degree of dissociation and the mechanistic pathway is highly complex with multiple competing routes. This is the accepted manuscript of a paper published in The Journal of Organic Chemistry, 2015, 80 (3), pp 1472\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd1498, DOI: 10.1021/jo502403n, Publication Date (Web): December 16, 2014 </summary> <dc:date>2014-12-16T00:00:00Z</dc:date> </entry> <entry> <title>Molecular containers in complex chemical systems</title> <link href="http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/246938" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name>Zarra, Salvatore</name> </author> <author> <name>Wood, Daniel M.</name> </author> <author> <name>Roberts, Derrick A.</name> </author> <author> <name>Nitschke, Jonathan R.</name> </author> <id>http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/246938</id> <updated>2015-03-06T09:40:45Z</updated> <published>2014-07-16T00:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">Molecular containers in complex chemical systems Zarra, Salvatore; Wood, Daniel M.; Roberts, Derrick A.; Nitschke, Jonathan R. Over the last decade molecular containers have been increasingly studied within the context of complex chemical systems. Herein we discuss selected examples from the literature concerning three aspects of this field: complex host\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdguest behaviour, adaptive transformations of molecular containers and reactivity modulation within them. This is the accepted manuscript. The final version is available from RSC at http://pubs.rsc.org/en/Content/ArticleLanding/2015/CS/c4cs00165f#!divAbstract. </summary> <dc:date>2014-07-16T00:00:00Z</dc:date> </entry> </feed>
